Award.AwardTitle: Management and Operation of the National Center for Atmospheric Research, 2008-2018, and Supporting Activities (DOE)

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project outcomes report represents projects that are funded by the Department of Energy (DOE) and awarded through the National Science Foundation (NSF) Cooperative Agreement to the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) for the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR).

This award provided funding for several Community Earth System Model (CESM) tutorials and Community Atmosphere Model (CAM) tutorials. These tutorials, hosted at NCAR, provided training for over three hundred participants.  Most of the students were graduate students, but several post-docs, faculty, and other research scientists also attended. The tutorials consisted of lectures and practical sessions conducted by NCAR.

The focus of the tutorials was on atmospheric modeling and touched on other aspects of earth system modeling, viewing the atmosphere as a coupled system. The tutorials provided an intense and immersive experience with super computers and climate models.  The content of the tutorials included basic lectures on climate modeling with a focus on the techniques and approaches used in CAM and specific lectures on detailed aspects of running and modifying the components of CAM and CESM. Instruction provided students and post-docs, as well as other researchers, with the knowledge and experience to use these models for research and applications. 

It is expected that former participants will disseminate the knowledge gained during attendance at tutorials amongst their colleagues at home institutions. NCAR has also created a website, which serves as a repository for all the course materials (htttp://www.cgd.ucar.edu/amp/tutorial). Over 900 people from about 40 countries have registered to access and use the tutorial materials. The online tutorial materials available from this activity are providing an important information resource for education in the use of CESM and CAM.

The projects trained and will continue to train a diverse group of students to use global climate models and to run the Community Atmosphere Model (CAM) and the Community Earth System Model (CESM).
